deck: Face Value Comics introduces Audiences to major characters with very real disorders in fictional metaphors, giving hope and inspiration and relatable Heroes to follow.
description: Combining Autism Awareness & Facial Feature Recognition on a static page, Face Value Comics is the 1st comics to feature an AUTISTIC hero in a Steampunk world with aliens & robots...& LOTS of misunderstanding. Adventures featuring unique characters in unique situations that young and old readers can get behind. Following rules based on the Comic Code Authority of a bygone era.
name: Face Value Comics

description:
A virtually unknown Australian publisher. Quoting Danny Best, "Not a great deal is known about Hubble, which might be due to his passing away before people such as Ryan began to actively track artists and writers down. Although some sites list him as being born in Adelaide, according to data maintained by the Black & White Artists Association he was born in Sydney in either 1903 or 1904 and passed away in 1960 (also in Sydney). In addition to his comic book work he dabbled in commercial and advertising art, as well working as a poet, salesman, writer and portrait painter." (See Best's blog on this topic, http://ohdannyboy.blogspot.com/2012/11/desert-dragon-comic-by-hub-rare-1946.html .)

Comics included Desert Dragon, Black Vulture, and Raybot.
name: Tom Hubble

description:
History

1909

Joris Lannoo starts the company in Tielt, Belgium. He buys a small press with the help of his parents. The same year the first publication rolls off the press: Vliegt de Blauwvoet?

1914-1919

WWI starts and Joris Lannoo serves in the Belgian Army as a volunteer. He serves till 1919 after which he starts building his publishing house. He signs authors like Albrecht Rodenbach, Guido Gezelle, Stijn Vermeulen and professor Frans Deels.

1926

A separate part of the business starts producing birth cards, death cards, wishing cards and menu cards. They're the basis for the current Lannoo Graphics.

1940-1945

Even during WWII Joris builds his business. He publishes what is later known as pocketbooks so everyone can own and read books.

1959

The family business is now 50 years old, it's time for the second generation, Godfried and Jan Lannoo, to take over.

1971

Joris Lannoo dies in Tielt. The business continues to grow rapidly under the new leadership of the two sons. The printer/publisher is awarded multiple prizes for the quality of their print work.

1980-1985

The third Lannoo generation now takes over the company and in 1981 they start their own design studio, Studio Lannoo, where they do all the graphics for their own books.

1991

The company is split into tow separate businesses: Uitgeverij Lannoo nv and Drukkerij Lannoo nv.

1994

Matthias Lannoo becomes the director of Uitgeverij Lannoo. DistriMedia nv. becomes the distributor center of Uitgeverij Lannoo.

1996

Lannoo Graphics stars a sales office in the Netherlands

1999

The company celebrates their 90th year in business with a new logo. They successfully take over Uiteverij Terra bv., an important Dutch publisher of lifestyle books.

2004

Lannoo Graphics starts an office in France to further fortify their graphic side of the business.
name: Lannoo

deck: Toon Books is an imprint of Candlewick Press that publishes comics-style readers for preschool- and school-aged children.
description:
History

Franoise Mouly, the art editor for The New Yorker, founded Toon Books in 2008, a decade after she had become an apologist for children's comics, first with RAW Junior, a spinoff of her RAW Books & Graphics, and then its anthology title Little Lit. With Toon Books, Mouly wanted to harness the medium to help children learn how, and why, to read. She recruited both authors and cartoonists to her cause and published six books in 2008. All were acclaimed.

In 2010, Toon Books became an imprint of Candlewick Press, which took on its sales, promotion, and distribution (this, through Random House Publisher Services). Since then, it has published more than a dozen books and has broken into the Will Eisner Comic Industry Awards, with five nominations in Best Publication for Early Readers.

In Education

To help children learn how to read, Toon Books presents its level-ed readers as comics, with balloons and panels to demonstrate dialogue and structure. They're double-checked by educators and test-driven by children until they're right for libraries and schools, where librarians and teachers may draw from ready-made lessons and worksheets, free of charge. That Toon Books is so thorough in the development and support of its readers says something for their caliber. If "Comics are a gateway drug to literacy" (as its Web site quotes Mouly's spouse, author Art Spiegelman), then the more educationally sound, and the more enjoyable, the comics, the better the trip.

Links

  • Facebook
  • Tumblr
  • Pinterest
  • YouTube
name: Toon Books

description:
History

Joost Nijsen started the company in 1997 when he took some Dutch authors with him when he left Nijgh & Van Ditmar en Balans. The independent publishing house set up it's roots in Amsterdam and specializes in current Dutch and translated literature (prose and poetry) and literate and journalistic non-fiction.

More than a publisher

Podium is not just a publisher, but for most of it's authors also their agent and act on their behalf in, not just book exploitation, but also translation rights, licensed reproductions, film and theater rights and all other forms of reproduction or adaptation of the original material.
name: UItgeverij Podium

description: Villard books started out as an independent imprint to Random House which is one of the largest publishing companies in the world. It currently (2013) serves as a sub-imprint of Ballantine Books which is itself also an imprint of Random House. Their web address leads straight to the Ballantine Books website.
name: Villard Books
